source: ETS Praxis School Psychologist Content Topics

topics.text: Understands various methods of information gathering (e.g., record review, interview strategies, observations, and testing [RIOT])
Understands appropriate use of background information (e.g., student records, medical records and reports, reviews of previous interventions, developmental history)
Understands appropriate use and interpretation of screening measures and methods
Understands theories of intelligence and the appropriate use and interpretation of measures of intellectual/cognitive functioning
Understands appropriate use and interpretation of measures of educational achievement
Knows appropriate use and interpretation of diagnostic/processing measures (e.g., memory, executive functioning, phonemic awareness)
Understands appropriate use and interpretation of measures of affective/social/emotional functioning and behavior
Knows appropriate use and interpretation of a functional behavioral assessment
Understands appropriate use and interpretation of performance-based assessment (e.g., work samples, portfolios)
Understands appropriate use and interpretation of curriculum-based assessment/curriculum-based measures
Knows appropriate use and interpretation of ecological assessment (e.g., classroom, family, community characteristics)
Knows how to use information and technology resources to enhance data collection and decision making
Understands the use of ongoing data collection to systematically assess the quality and effectiveness of academic, mental health, and system-level services

sections.name: Knowledge of measurement theory and principles

topics.text: Knows how to use a problem-solving framework as the basis for all professional activities (e.g., Multitiered System of Supports, Response to Intervention)
Understands the use and interpretation of different types of test scores and norms (e.g., grade- and age-referenced)
Knows the strengths and limitations of various types of assessment procedures (e.g., self-report tests and inventories, multiple-choice tests, interviews)
Knows the principles of reliability and validity
Knows personal, social, linguistic, environmental, racial, and cultural factors that may influence assessment procedures
Knows about test fairness and equity concepts (e.g., implicit bias, explicit bias)
Understands appropriate use and interpretation of measures of developmental and adaptive functioning across all age groups

Knows appropriate use and interpretation of assessment procedures for English as second language/English-language learners (e.g., the appropriate use of translators/interpreters, measurement selection, language of assessment)
Is familiar with the assessment of students with low-incidence exceptionalities (e.g., chronic health impairments, severe physical disabilities, sensory impairments)

sections.name: Models and methods of consultation used for planning, implementing, and evaluating academic interventions and mental health services

topics.text: Knows strategies for consultation (e.g., goal setting, record keeping, evaluating progress) and how to use a problem-solving framework as the basis for all consultation and collaboration activities when planning, implementing, and evaluating academic and mental health services
Knows the principles and strategies associated with varied models of consultation
Knows how to facilitate communication and collaboration among diverse stakeholders (e.g., school personnel, families, community professionals)
Knows strategies for working with diverse families (e.g., building relationships, collaborating on intervention plans, promoting positive habits)
Knows strategies for working with diverse community agencies/providers to support a student's success

sections.name: Effective instruction at the individual and group level

topics.text: Is familiar with various instructional strategies (e.g., cooperative learning, differentiated instruction, engagement time, scaffolding, study skills)
Knows common curricular accommodations and modifications (e.g., information and assistive technology, specially designed instruction, test format)
Knows methods for setting and achieving individual instructional goals, assessing outcomes to see whether goals were attained, and helping students become self-regulated learners
Knows how to identify and use evidence-based strategies when planning interventions and instructional strategies
Knows factors related to academic progress (e.g., school/classroom climate, family involvement, motivation, socioeconomic and environmental factors, language competency, programming for ELLs)
Understands the biological, cultural, developmental, and social influences on academic skills

sections.name: Primary, secondary, and tertiary preventive strategies

topics.text: Is familiar with common classroom organization and management techniques (e.g., time management, classroom rules, physical environment)
Knows how to conduct individual and small-group interventions and programs (e.g., social skills training, conflict resolution)
Is familiar with risk and protective factors associated with learning and mental and behavioral health issues; designs appropriate intervention plans to address those issues
Knows the impact of trauma on social, emotional, behavioral, and academic functioning; practices to reduce the effects of trauma on learning and behavior
Understands fundamental counseling methods (e.g., individual, group) and techniques (e.g., active listening, unconditional positive regard, empathy)
Knows about appropriate intervention techniques for various developmental levels
Is familiar with various theoretical models and approaches to counseling (e.g., cognitive-behavioral, solution-focused)
Understands applied behavioral analysis and intervention methods
Knows culturally responsive and developmentally appropriate assessment techniques to identify emotional and behavioral disabilities
Knows how to use data to evaluate implementation and outcomes of mental and behavioral health interventions for individuals and groups
Is familiar with common characteristics of mental health problems and related educational disabilities
Understands the impact mental health has on the educational outcomes of children and adolescents
Understands the biological, cultural, developmental, and social influences on mental and behavioral health
Is familiar with the importance of using data to inform systems-level decision making, such as needs assessment, universal screening, and resource mapping

Is familiar with the effectiveness of the practices in the context of common educational policies/practices (e.g., social promotion, high-stakes testing, benchmarking, retention, tracking, discipline)
Recognizes the importance of using evidence-based practices
Understands the application of effective Multitiered Systems of Support

sections.name: Services to Promote Safe and Supportive Schools

topics.text: Knows common school/system-wide prevention practices (e.g., promoting safe school environments, positive behavioral support, bullying prevention, school climate assessment, policy development, programs promoting good health)
Knows risk and protective factors as they relate to a variety of issues such as school failure, truancy, dropout, bullying, youth suicide, school violence
Knows interventions appropriate for the various levels of crisis and threat assessment associated with suicide and violence assessment
Is familiar with factors and issues that should be addressed in crisis prevention, intervention, response, and recovery at the system level

Is familiar with effective methods to measure and evaluate school safety and school climate (e.g., attendance; office discipline referrals; academic growth; universal screening of students, staff, and families; mental health referrals)
Understands principles and research related to family systems, strengths, needs, and cultures
Is familiar with the importance of advocating for the involvement of families in schoolwide activities
Is familiar with the importance of interagency collaboration in developing effective schoolwide interventions and policies
Is familiar with strategies for safe, nurturing, and dependable parenting and home interventions to facilitate children's healthy development

sections.name: Equitable Practices for Diverse Student Populations

topics.text: Recognizes the importance and influence of culture, background, and individual learning characteristics (e.g., age, gender identity, cognitive capabilities, social-emotional skills, developmental level, race, ethnicity, national origin, religion, sexual orientation, disability, chronic illness, language, socioeconomic status) when designing and implementing interventions to achieve learning and behavioral outcomes
Knows the importance of working with community liaisons to understand the needs of diverse learners
Knows the impact of personal beliefs as well as implicit and explicit bias that influence decision making, instruction, behavior, and long-term outcomes for students
Recognizes the importance of promoting fairness and social justice in educational programs and services

Knows about special education and related services; knows how to promote specialized instructional and support practices within special education that meet the diverse needs of children with disabilities
Knows how to evaluate research quality and interpret outcomes
Knows how to determine the relevance of research and apply research into practice
Is familiar with types of research designs and basic statistics
Is familiar with the process involved in implementing individual- and system-level change, including planning and evaluating activities, monitoring fidelity, and addressing barriers to change
Knows how to incorporate data collection, measurement, analysis, accountability, and use of technology resources into program evaluation
Knows how to analyze, interpret, and use research-based and evidence-based practices at the individual, group, and/or systems levels

sections.name: Ethical principles related to the practice of school psychology

topics.text: Understands the NASP Principles for Professional Ethics
Knows how to apply an ethical problem-solving model to address ethical dilemmas

sections.name: Legal issues related to the practice of school psychology

topics.text: Knows the major federal laws and regulations governing the practice of school psychology (e.g., FERPA, Section 504, ESSA, IDEA and its eligibility categories)
Knows relevant case law that affects practice (e.g., Larry P. v. Riles, Hendrick Hudson Board of Education v. Rowley, Endrew F. v. Douglas County School District)
Knows the rights of students (e.g., informed consent, confidentiality, least restrictive environment, manifestation determination, seclusion and restraint)
Knows the ethical, professional, and legal liability of school psychologists (e.g., malpractice, negligence, supervision, conflict of interest)
Understands the ethical and legal responsibilities of advocating for children and their families (i.e., issues such as disproportionality, poverty, access, and equity)
Recognizes the importance of lifelong learning and professional growth
Is familiar with the importance and value of supervision and mentoring
